normalised: wildlife conservation, especially here in india, is about more than just protecting animals; it’s about preserving our heritage, our ecosystems, and ultimately, our future. think of the bengal tiger – a national symbol, but sadly, its population faced dire straits not so long ago.

normalised: why is conservation so crucial? well, healthy wildlife populations play vital roles in maintaining ecosystem balance. they help with pollination, seed dispersal, and controlling pest populations. removing a key species can trigger a cascade of negative effects.

unnormalised: Why is conservation so crucial? Well, healthy wildlife populations play vital roles in maintaining ecosystem balance. They help with pollination, seed dispersal, and controlling pest populations. Removing a key species can trigger a cascade of negative effects.
normalised: in india, initiatives like project tiger, launched on first april one thousand nine hundred and seventy three, have been instrumental in bolstering tiger numbers. there's also significant work happening at institutions like the wildlife institute of india (W I I) in dehradun. they conduct vital research and training to improve conservation efforts. local communities are also being increasingly involved, recognizing that their traditional knowledge is invaluable.

unnormalised: In India, initiatives like Project Tiger, launched on 1st April 1973, have been instrumental in bolstering tiger numbers.
